Getting Started with psychinterpreter

LLM-Powered Interpretation of Psychometric Analyses

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-16

Source: vignettes/articles/01-Getting_Started.qmd

What is psychinterpreter?

The psychinterpreter package automatically interprets psychometric analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs). LLMs are AI systems (like ChatGPT, Claude, or open-source alternatives) that can understand and generate human-like text. Instead of manually examining complex statistical output and guessing what patterns represent, you get clear, human-readable interpretations and actionable insights.

Currently supported analyses:

  • Factor Analysis - Interpret factor loadings and suggest meaningful factor names

Planned analysis classes:

  • Gaussian Mixture Models - Interpret cluster profiles
  • Item Response Theory (IRT) - Interpret item diagnostics
  • Cognitive Diagnostic Models (CDM) - Interpret Q-matrix patterns

Use this package when you:

  • Have run a psychometric analysis (e.g., factor analysis, clustering)
  • Want automated, data-driven interpretations of your results
  • Need to quickly understand complex patterns in your data

What You Need

Before starting, make sure you have:

  1. Analysis results - from psych::fa(), lavaan::efa(), or similar functions
  2. Variable descriptions - brief explanations of what each variable measures
  3. A language model - we recommend Ollama (free, runs locally, offers cloud-powered models if you have an Ollama account)

Quick Start Example

Here’s a complete workflow for factor analysis using Big Five personality data in just a few lines:

Code
library(psychinterpreter)
library(psych)
library(ollamar)

# 1. Run factor analysis
fa_result <- psych::fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")

# 2. Describe your variables
var_info <- data.frame(
  variable = c("A1", "A2", "A3", ...),
  description = c("Am indifferent to others", "Inquire about others", ...)
)

# 3. Get LLM interpretation
interpretation <- interpret(
  fit_results = fa_result,
  variable_info = var_info,
  llm_provider = "ollama",
  llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"
)

# 4. View results
print(interpretation)
plot(interpretation)

Step-by-Step Tutorial: Factor Analysis

This tutorial demonstrates the package using factor analysis, but the same workflow applies to other analysis types when they become available.

Let’s walk through a complete example using the Big Five Inventory (BFI) personality data.

Setup

Load the packages we’ll need:

Code
# Install pacman if needed for easy package loading
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")

# Load packages
pacman::p_load(
  "psychinterpreter",  # This package
  "psych",             # For factor analysis
  "DT",        # For nice tables
  "dplyr",             # For data manipulation
  "pander"             # package for pretty printing
)

Load and Prepare Data

The BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring the Big Five traits.

Code
# Load Big Five Inventory data
data("bfi")
data("bfi.dictionary")

# Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics)
bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25]
bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ]

Here’s what the data looks like:

Code
head(bfi_items, 5) |>
  as.data.frame() |>
   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

And here are the item descriptions:

Code
bfi_dict |>
  select(Item) |>
  as.data.frame() |>
  DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

Run Factor Analysis

Perform a standard exploratory factor analysis with 5 factors:

Code
fa_result <- psych::fa(
  bfi_items,
  nfactors = 5,
  rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation
  fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood
)

View the factor loadings:

Code
# Extract and display loadings
loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> 
  as.data.frame()

round(loadings_matrix, 2) |> 
  DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

Prepare Variable Descriptions

Create a data frame mapping variable names to their descriptions:

Code
variable_info <- data.frame(
  variable = rownames(bfi_dict),
  description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

head(variable_info, 10) |> 
  DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

Get LLM Interpretation

Now use interpret() to get automatic factor interpretations:

Code
interpretation <- interpret(
  fit_results = fa_result,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  llm_provider = "ollama",
  llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud"
)

FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Number of factors: 5
Loading cutoff: 0.3
LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud
Tokens:
  Input: 1780
  Output: 5777
Elapsed time: 29.5

SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Factor 1 (9.6%): Negative Affectivity
• Factor 2 (7.7%): Warmth & Empathy
• Factor 3 (7.4%): Introverted Reflection
• Factor 4 (7.7%): Perfectionist Conscientiousness
• Factor 5 (6.3%): Creative Social Insight

Total variance explained: 38.7%

FACTOR CORRELATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

ML2: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01
ML5: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23
ML1: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17
ML3: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20
ML4: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20

DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Factor 1 (ML2) - Negative Affectivity
Number of significant loadings: 5
Variance explained: 9.65%
Factor Correlations: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01

Variables:
  1. N1, Get angry easily. (, , .852)
  2. N2, Get irritated easily. (, , .817)
  3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (, , .665)
  4. N5, Panic easily. (, , .439)
  5. N4, Often feel blue. (, , .413)

LLM Interpretation:
ML2 captures core Neuroticism, with high loadings on anger, irritability, mood swings, sadness, and panic. The construct
represents emotional instability and frequent negative affect. These variables converge to form a cohesive “Negative
Affectivity” factor, explaining 9.6 % of overall variance. Its modest correlations with other factors (e.g., -.03 with
ML5, .23 with ML1) suggest it is distinct yet shares a slight positive link with extraversion‑related traits. The factor
shows excellent convergent validity, as all five high‑loading items consistently reflect the same affective domain.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 2 (ML5) - Warmth & Empathy
Number of significant loadings: 7
Variance explained: 7.69%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23

Variables:
  1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (, , .668)
  2. A2, Inquire about others' well-being. (, , .603)
  3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (, , .577)
  4. A4, Love children. (, , .456)
  5. E4, Make friends easily. (, , .362)
  6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (, , -.360)
  7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , .303)

LLM Interpretation:
ML5 embodies Agreeableness and Social Warmth, with strong loadings on interpersonal concern (Ask about well‑being),
comfort skills (Know how to comfort), and empathy (Make people feel at ease). Its moderate loadings from extroverted
actions (Make friends easily) and thoughtfulness (Avoid difficult reading) reflect a balanced, considerate disposition.
The factor accounts for 7.7 % of variance and shows weak negative correlations with ML2 (‑.03) and modest positive liens
with ML4 (.23) and ML1 (‑.31), indicating it’s largely distinct from affective and extraverted constructs while offering
complementary insights.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 3 (ML1) - Introverted Reflection
Number of significant loadings: 7
Variance explained: 7.36%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17

Variables:
  1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (, , .667)
  2. E1, Don't talk a lot. (, , .565)
  3. E4, Make friends easily. (, , -.527)
  4. N4, Often feel blue. (, , .420)
  5. E5, Take charge. (, , -.394)
  6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (, , .357)
  7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , -.341)

LLM Interpretation:
ML1 reflects Introverted Reflection, integrating high loadings on reserved extraversion items (Don’t talk a lot, Find it
difficult to approach others) and low assertiveness indicators (Know how to captivate, Make friends easily, Take
charge). The additional positive loading on Reflective Thinking (Spend time reflecting) and modest positive mood cues
(Often feel blue, Panic) suggest a conscientious, self‑contained orientation. Accounting for 7.4 % of variance, this
factor presents moderate correlations with extraversion (ML5, .23) but remains largely independent of neuroticism (ML2,
.23) and conscientiousness (ML3, −.22).

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 4 (ML3) - Perfectionist Conscientiousness
Number of significant loadings: 5
Variance explained: 7.71%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20

Variables:
  1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (, , -.643)
  2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (, , .638)
  3. C5, Waste my time. (, , -.570)
  4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (, , .564)
  5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (, , .532)

LLM Interpretation:
ML3 captures Conscientiousness‑Perfect, dominated by high loadings on diligent planning and order (Exacting work,
Continue until perfect, Do things according to a plan) and negatively on half‑way and wasted work, underscoring a
disciplined, perfectionistic ethos. The modest positive loading on making people feel at ease (A5) hints at a prosocial
element. Explaining 7.7 % of the variance, the factor shows small inverse ties to extraversion (ML1, −.22) and modest
positive links to Agreeableness and Creativity (ML4, .20, .23), and further enrich the model.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 5 (ML4) - Creative Social Insight
Number of significant loadings: 6
Variance explained: 6.25%
Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20

Variables:
  1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (, , .633)
  2. O1, Am full of ideas. (, , .534)
  3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (, , -.522)
  4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (, , -.441)
  5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (, , .379)
  6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , .315)

LLM Interpretation:
ML4 illustrates Creative Social Insight, merging high loadings from idea generation (Full of ideas, Carry conversation
to a higher level) and social charm (Know how to captivate, Take charge) with a tendency to avoid deep probing and
complex reading. This factor embodies a sociable, imaginative orientation emphasizing surface‑level elaboration. It
accounts for 6.3 % of total variance and shows weak negative ties to neuroticism (ML2, −.01) but relatively stronger
positive relations with Agreeableness (ML5, .23) and Introverted Reflection (ML1, −.17), reflecting its complementary
yet distinct nature.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

CROSS-LOADING VARIABLES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):
- E3: ML5 (.303), ML1 (-.341), ML4 (.315)
- E4: ML5 (.362), ML1 (-.527)
- N4: ML2 (.413), ML1 (.420)
- O4: ML1 (.357), ML4 (.379)

Note

First time using Ollama?

  1. Install Ollama from ollama.com and the ollamar package: install.packages("ollamar")
  2. Pull the model: ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud")
  3. Start the Ollama server before running interpret()

View Results

Print the interpretation report:

Code
print(interpretation)

CROSS-LOADING VARIABLES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3):
- E3: ML5 (.303), ML1 (-.341), ML4 (.315)
- E4: ML5 (.362), ML1 (-.527)
- N4: ML2 (.413), ML1 (.420)
- O4: ML1 (.357), ML4 (.379)

The output shows: - Suggested factor names - Which variables load on each factor - A brief interpretation of what the factor represents

View suggested factor names:

Code
suggested_names <- interpretation$suggested_names |>
  unlist()

data.frame(Suggested_Factor_Name = suggested_names) |>
  DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE), colnames = "Suggested Factor Name")

Visualize Factor Structure

Create a visual representation of the factor loadings:

Code
plot(interpretation, cutoff = 0.3)

This plot shows which variables load strongly on each factor, making it easy to see the factor structure at a glance.

Export Results

Save your interpretation to a file:

Code
# Export as markdown
export_interpretation(
  interpretation,
  format = "md",
  file = "bfi_interpretation"
)

# Export as plain text
export_interpretation(
  interpretation,
  format = "txt",
  file = "bfi_interpretation"
)

Customizing Your Interpretation

You can control several aspects of the interpretation:

Key parameters:

  • cutoff: Threshold for displaying results (e.g., minimum loading for FA)
  • hide_low_loadings: Whether to hide loadings below the cutoff from the LLM
  • word_limit: Control how verbose the LLM interpretations are
  • output_format: Choose between plain text or markdown formatting
  • heading_level: Heading level to start the report with.
Code
interpretation <- interpret(
  fit_results = fa_result,
  variable_info = variable_info,
  llm_provider = "ollama",
  llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",

  cutoff = 0.4,              # Threshold for including results (default: 0.3)
  hide_low_loadings = TRUE,  # hide low loadings below cutoff from the LLM
  word_limit = 30,          # Max words per interpretation (default: 150)
  output_format = "markdown",# Output format: "text" or "markdown"
  heading_level = 3,         # set heading level for markdown output
)

Loading cutoff: 0.4
LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud

Output: 2067

Marked by low talkativeness, difficulty initiating contact, and a tendency to find forming friendships challenging, this factor captures a reserved, withdrawn social approach in daily contexts and interpersonal interactions.

  5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (, , .532)

LLM Interpretation:
High adherence to exacting standards, thorough planning, and relentless pursuit of perfection, coupled with a low tolerance for mediocrity or wasted effort, defines this diligent conscientiousness.

  4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (, , -.441)

LLM Interpretation:
Tendency to generate numerous ideas and elevate conversations, yet showing limited engagement with complex material or probing depth, reflecting a creative yet somewhat superficial cognitive style.

  • E3 (highest: ML1 = .341)
  • E5 (highest: ML1 = .394)
  • O4 (highest: ML4 = .379)

Common Questions

Q: What if the LLM interpretation seems wrong?

The LLM bases interpretations on your variable descriptions and statistical results. You can:

  • Provide better, more descriptive variable descriptions
  • Use a bigger LLM. Small models may struggle with the task and structured output requirements.
  • Adjust the cutoff and hide_low_loadings parameters to change which results are included
  • Add context with the additional_info parameter

Q: Can I use different LLMs?

Yes! The package supports all providers supported by the ellmer package, for example:

  • Ollama (local, free): llm_provider = "ollama"
  • OpenAI (API key required): llm_provider = "openai"
  • Anthropic Claude (API key required): llm_provider = "anthropic"

Q: How do I set API keys for OpenAI or Anthropic?

Code
# Add to your .Renviron file:
Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-key-here")
Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "your-key-here")

Also refer to the documentation of the ellmer https://ellmer.tidyverse.org/ package.
